data.name: Is it a Tree?
data.description:
# Abstract:
  In mathematics, and more specifically in graph theory, a tree is an undirected graph in which any two vertices are connected by exactly one path. In other words, any acyclic connected graph is a tree.
  There are plenty of advantages of using tree instead of graphs. 
  So how can we find if a given graph is a tree?

![alt text][logo1]

[logo1]:https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/24/Tree_graph.svg
# Description:
You will be given a graph represented by an adjancy list and the number of vertices that graph has.
 
```C 
int isTree (Graph * g, int NV);

```
An adjancy list is and array where each indice represents a vertice, each indice will be pointer to a list of the type ... 

```C 
typedef struct edge {
  int dest ;
  struct edge * prox;
} * Graph , Node;
```
In case you are with trouble understanding how adjancy lists work
the code bellow might give some intuitions. 

```C
void print_edges(Graph *g, int NV) {
    struct edge *e;
    int i;
    for (i = 0; i < NV; ++i)
        for (e = g[i]; e; e = e->prox)
            printf("%d - %d\n", i, e->dest);
}
```
You can find more about adjancy lists in the link bellow.
(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adjacency_list)

To complete this task you will have to find if the given graph is a tree.
You should return 1 in the afirmitive case and 0 otherwise.

```
Example 1: True (1)
```
![alt text][logo2]

[logo2]:https://www.tutorialspoint.com/graph_theory/images/tree.jpg


```
Example 2: True (1)
``` 
![alt text][logo3]

```
Example 3: False (0)
``` 
![alt text][logo4]

[logo3]:http://d1hyf4ir1gqw6c.cloudfront.net/wp-content/uploads/image4.png

[logo4]:https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Directed_graph,_cyclic.svg/2000px-Directed_graph,_cyclic.svg.png
